title: Logic Concepts
description: Basic understanding of logical terms and concepts in discrete mathematics.

questions.question: A statement that can only be true or false, but not both, is called a _____.
questions.explanation: A proposition has a definite truth value - it must be either true or false, but cannot be both.

questions.question: What is a predicate?
options: A sentence that is always true
A sentence with a variable that becomes a statement when the variable is replaced
A sentence that is always false
A sentence that combines multiple statements
questions.explanation: A predicate is a sentence containing a variable which becomes a statement when that variable is replaced with a specific value.

questions.question: The statement '2 + 2 = 5' is:
options: A valid statement that is true
A valid statement that is false
questions.explanation: This is a valid statement because it has a definite truth value (it's false), but it's still a proper statement.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a statement?
questions.explanation: x + 3 = 7 is a predicate because it contains a variable x. It becomes a statement only when x is replaced with a specific value.

questions.question: What type of logical statement is always true regardless of the truth values of its components?
questions.explanation: A tautology is a compound statement that is always true regardless of the truth values of its components.

questions.question: Which of the following is a compound statement?
options: If it rains, then the ground is wet
questions.explanation: A compound statement combines two or more simple statements using logical connectives. 'If it rains, then the ground is wet' uses the if-then connective.

questions.question: What is a statement that is always false called?
questions.explanation: A contradiction is a compound statement that is always false regardless of the truth values of its components.

questions.question: Which has the highest precedence in logical operations?
questions.explanation: The NOT operator (¬) has the highest precedence among all logical operators.

questions.question: ¬(P ∧ Q) is equivalent to _____.
questions.explanation: By De Morgan's Law, the negation of a conjunction (AND) becomes the disjunction (OR) of the negations: ¬(P ∧ Q) ≡ ¬P ∨ ¬Q

questions.question: Which is a tautology?
questions.explanation: P ∨ ¬P (read as 'P or not P') is always true regardless of P's truth value, making it a tautology.

title: Symbolic Translation
description: Translation between English sentences and logical symbols.

questions.question: If I sleep, then I rest well is false only when _____.
questions.explanation: An implication (P → Q) is false only when the antecedent (P) is true and the consequent (Q) is false. In this case, when 'sleep' is true but 'rest well' is false.

questions.question: I will sleep only if I finish my homework translates to _____.
questions.explanation: When we say 'X only if Y', it translates to X → Y. In this case, Sleep → Homework.

questions.question: Neither rain nor shine translates to _____.
questions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' is the negation of OR, thus it translates to ¬(P ∨ Q).

questions.question: Given P: 'It is raining' and Q: 'The ground is wet', which symbolic form represents 'It is not raining but the ground is wet'?
questions.explanation: The statement combines 'not raining' (¬P) with 'ground is wet' (Q) using 'but' which translates to AND (∧).

questions.question: Given P: 'You study hard' and Q: 'You pass the exam', translate 'You pass the exam only if you study hard' into symbols.
questions.explanation: 'Only if' means the condition is necessary. Q → P means 'if you pass (Q), then you must have studied (P)'.

questions.question: If P: 'It is sunny' and Q: 'I go to the beach', which symbolic form represents 'I go to the beach if and only if it is sunny'?
questions.explanation: The statement 'if and only if' is represented by the biconditional operator ↔.

questions.question: Given P: 'I study' and Q: 'I pass the exam', translate 'I study but I don't pass the exam' into symbols.
questions.explanation: The word 'but' translates to AND (∧), and 'don't pass' is the negation of Q (¬Q).

questions.question: Which English sentence correctly represents P → Q?
options: P if and only if Q
questions.explanation: The symbol → represents an if-then relationship between P and Q.

questions.question: The contrapositive of 'If it rains, then the road is wet' is _____.
options: If it doesn't rain, then the road isn't wet
If the road isn't wet, then it didn't rain
If the road is wet, then it rained
The road is wet and it rained
questions.explanation: The contrapositive (¬Q → ¬P) is logically equivalent to the original statement (P → Q). Here, it's 'If the road isn't wet (¬Q), then it didn't rain (¬P)'.

questions.question: If I am hungry, then I will eat and drink translates to _____.
questions.explanation: The consequent contains two actions joined by 'and', so both Q and R follow from P: P → (Q ∧ R).

questions.question: It is not true that both A and B are happy translates to _____.
questions.explanation: This is a negation of a conjunction. The entire 'A and B are happy' (A ∧ B) is negated: ¬(A ∧ B).

title: Proof by Invalidity
description: Understanding and identifying invalid logical arguments.

questions.question: Which argument form represents Modus Ponens?
questions.explanation: Modus Ponens is the valid argument form: If P implies Q (P → Q), and P is true, then Q must be true (∴ Q).

questions.question: Which argument form represents the fallacy of affirming the consequent?
questions.explanation: The fallacy of affirming the consequent occurs when we conclude P from P → Q and Q. This is invalid because Q could be true for other reasons.

questions.question: Given the premises: 1) If it rains, the ground is wet (P → Q), 2) The ground is not wet (¬Q). What is the valid conclusion?
options: No valid conclusion can be drawn
questions.explanation: This is an example of modus tollens: If P → Q and ¬Q, then ¬P must be true.

questions.question: When is an argument considered invalid?
options: When all premises are true and the conclusion is true
When there exists a case where all premises are true but the conclusion is false
When the conclusion is always true
questions.explanation: An argument is invalid if there's any possible case where all premises could be true while the conclusion is false.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of the fallacy of affirming the consequent?
options: If P then Q, P, therefore Q
If P then Q, Q, therefore P
If P then Q, not Q, therefore not P
If P then Q, not P, therefore not Q
questions.explanation: The fallacy of affirming the consequent occurs when we conclude P from 'If P then Q' and Q.

questions.question: In a valid argument, if all premises are true:
options: The truth of the conclusion is independent
questions.explanation: A valid argument guarantees that if all premises are true, the conclusion must also be true.

questions.question: Which argument represents a valid disjunctive syllogism?
questions.explanation: Disjunctive syllogism states that if we have P OR Q, and we know that P is false, then Q must be true.

questions.question: Which represents a valid hypothetical syllogism?
questions.explanation: Hypothetical syllogism chains implications: if P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R.

title: Infix to Postfix Conversion
description: Converting infix expressions to postfix notation.

questions.question: Convert the infix expression (A ∧ B) ∨ (C ∧ D) to postfix notation.
questions.explanation: In postfix notation, we process the inner parentheses first: (A ∧ B) becomes 'A B ∧', (C ∧ D) becomes 'C D ∧', then join with ∨: 'A B ∧ C D ∧ ∨'.

questions.question: Convert the infix expression ¬(A ∨ B) to postfix notation.
questions.explanation: First process within parentheses (A ∨ B), then apply negation to the result, giving us 'A B ∨ ¬'.

questions.question: In operator precedence for logical operators, which of these is correctly ordered from highest to lowest precedence?
questions.explanation: The correct precedence order from highest to lowest is: NOT (¬), AND (∧), OR (∨), IMPLIES (→), IF AND ONLY IF (↔).

questions.question: What is the first step when converting an infix expression to postfix?
options: Scan the expression from right to left
Scan the expression from left to right
questions.explanation: The first step in converting infix to postfix is to scan the expression from left to right, processing operands and operators according to rules.

questions.question: What is the postfix form of the expression: A ∧ (B ∨ C)?
questions.explanation: Converting step by step: A remains, then B and C are processed with ∨, finally ∧ is applied to A and (B∨C).

questions.question: Which operator has the highest precedence in logical expressions?
questions.explanation: The NOT operator (¬) has the highest precedence among logical operators.

questions.question: What is the postfix form of ¬(A ∨ B)?
questions.explanation: First A and B are connected by ∨, then the entire expression is negated, resulting in AB∨¬.

questions.question: Convert the infix expression (A ∨ B) → (C ∨ D) to postfix notation.
questions.explanation: Process left parentheses first (A ∨ B), then right parentheses (C ∨ D), finally apply →: AB∨CD∨→

questions.question: Convert the infix expression (A ↔ B) ∧ C to postfix notation.
questions.explanation: First process the biconditional within parentheses (A ↔ B), then apply ∧ with C: AB↔C∧

title: Logical Operators and Truth Tables
description: Understanding truth tables and logical operators in discrete mathematics.

questions.question: If P: '2 + 2 = 4' and Q: '3 > 5', then P ∧ Q is _____.
questions.explanation: Since P is true (2 + 2 = 4) but Q is false (3 is not greater than 5), and conjunction (∧) requires both operands to be true, P ∧ Q is false.

questions.question: What is a truth table with 3 variables guaranteed to have?
questions.explanation: For n variables, a truth table has 2^n rows. With 3 variables, we have 2^3 = 8 rows.

questions.question: What is the truth value of P ∧ Q when P is true and Q is false?
questions.explanation: For AND (∧) operation, both operands must be true for the result to be true. If either is false, the result is false.

questions.question: What is the truth value of P ∨ Q when P is false and Q is true?
questions.explanation: For OR (∨) operation, if at least one operand is true, the result is true. Here Q is true, so P ∨ Q is true.

questions.question: What is the truth value of P → Q when P is false and Q is true?
questions.explanation: An implication P → Q is false only when P is true and Q is false. In all other cases, including when P is false, the implication is true.

questions.question: Which of these logical equivalences is NOT correct?
questions.explanation: P ∨ Q is NOT equivalent to ¬P ∧ ¬Q. The correct equivalence by De Morgan's Law would be ¬(P ∨ Q) ≡ ¬P ∧ ¬Q.

questions.question: When evaluating ¬P ∨ (P ∧ Q), which operator should be applied first?
questions.explanation: While ¬ has highest precedence, operations in parentheses must be evaluated first. So we evaluate (P ∧ Q), then apply ¬ to P, and finally the ∨.
